On july 30, 2014
Corvus Cloud

Updated October 22 2015

Griefing is not allowed in Die2Nite. Those that do grief will receive a warning along with a two week ban. If they choose to ignore the warning and continue, their Twinoid account will be deleted.

However, there is a difference between griefing and selfish play. Selfish play still is and will continue to be allowed. So how do we tell the difference?

Griefing is a series of deliberate actions taken solely to harm the town with no benefit to oneself.

Selfish Play includes actions which may harm others, but still allows for personal gain. However, punching others and "hiding" from retaliation does rise to the level of griefing. Important Update: Extreme examples of selfish play prior to day 5 may fall into our new griefing policies. You are still free to boost your own survival chances at any time, but actively trying to kill others through selfish play mechanisms are now disallowed prior to day 5.

Generally, griefing falls into a few specific scenarios.

1) Griefer punches as many people as possible, hides at 0/0 then dies during the first few days of the town by running into the desert or by some other deliberate action at any point during the town. Important Update: Repeatedly attacking people recklessly in the first days of town can be considered griefing and will be dealt with accordingly.

2) Griefer takes some or all important items from the bank (that provide no benefit in the world outside) and runs outside to die.

If you find someone that's actually griefing your town (and not just playing selfishly), send a message to the "Die2Nite Crows" inbox on this page with screenshots and details of what they've done. We do review all reports and take the appropriate actions (if any), but will not generally respond to messages unless we need more information.

If you do not have an easy screenshot utility, follow these few simple steps:
1) Press the PrintScreen button on your keyboard
2) Go to http://www.imgur.com (no account required!)
3) Press the Upload Images button in the top menu bar
4) Press Ctrl+V (or whatever normal paste combination your computer uses) - if you do this in a different tab, it can be repeated as many times as needed with different images
5) Press Start Upload button above your preview(s)
6) (optional) You can edit your images within Imgur to crop unnecessary parts by clicking appropriate links.
7) Get album/image link from URL bar and send to the Crow inbox (linked above)

DO NOT "name and shame" players in this thread. Send your reports in and let us figure it out. If there's action to be taken, we'll take it.

On august 3, 2014
Corvus Epithumia

The point of the one to two day limitation is to still allow for selfish play which is well within the rules of the game.

Someone that punches people then stays in town to compete for LMS is a valid strategy. Arguably distasteful, but valid. It's the people that punch then stay outside to die with no intention of doing anything other than harming the people and the town that we're trying to cut down on.

If you can make a valid case that someone was griefing and not just playing selfishly, you're welcome to report it. But understand that it becomes a grey area past day 1 and exponentially so past day 2.

If you have a problem with a griefer, report them as Cloud laid out in the original post and let us deal with them. Other than that, posting logs just seems like spam and thread derailment.

That said, I don't see a need to warn for it unless it truly becomes spammy if people start posting oodles of logs.

Fortis

When you say "screen shots" are you meaning that I need to provide links to pictures? Or is it sufficient to past the text in from the suspect's house? I assume you investigate the actual town logs and don't depend on what is provided and pictures because pictures can be faked too. It is much easier to past the text into a PM.
On august 5, 2014
Corvus Epithumia
FortisWhen you say "screen shots" are you meaning that I need to provide links to pictures? Or is it sufficient to past the text in from the suspect's house? I assume you investigate the actual town logs and don't depend on what is provided and pictures because pictures can be faked too. It is much easier to past the text into a PM.

Screenshots are better, logs are ok. There are tons of screenshot utilities that make it incredibly easy to capture the whole screen or even a portion and automatically upload to a free server.

That said, as Moderators, Cloud, coro and I do not have access to town registries or town logs. We do, however, have access to Map Viewer town information just like the rest of the community and can get a pretty good idea of what's going on from there.

What we're looking for is evidence of actual griefer play styles. We need to see the logs of them punching other players, we need to see them hanging out at 0/0 (this is especially where a screenshot is handy from the citizens page) and we need to see that they've died on day one or two by their own actions.

Part of the reason we prefer screenshots is that it's much more difficult or time consuming to doctor. We want to see the person's full actions for the day, even if that means multiple screenshots. We don't want a selective copy/paste of just the punches or other negative actions without the rest of the context.

If there is any doubt and we can't agree that it is or is not griefing, we can ask Buzzard to take a look at the actual logs.

We are working with Motion Twin to expand our scope from the current policy regarding 0/0 punchers and apply these same policies to griefing in general. On march 22, 2015
MrIcy

We should perhaps amend the word "griefing" to "trolling" as it implies giving others grief rather than being the offended party themselves.

It is fine if someone occasionally runs away with the best items or occasionally uses all the boosters to wound people or occasionally closes the gates due to various grievances. However, it should not be ok if someone regularly does this in most every town they are in.

Truth be told, most people playing random hardcore towns are in it for LMS and therefore selfish reasons. Though, if you punch citizens, use up boosters, play with the gates (and so on) early in the town in EVERY town you are in, then this will result in you being shunned, hanged, wounded etc. You may even succeed in getting rid of a few people, but this will make it harder for you to obtain LMS as you lose access to the bank and are more likely to die due to getting punched, hanged, meatlockered or not being able to load up on DOs prior to the breach.

LMS cannot be gained prior to day 5 and depending on the town is usually gained a couple of days thereafter. Performing these actions early on is clearly trolling and not selfish play at all.

As for the person that cannot be named that we all know of, I have seen him do this across many towns, including my current town and he is definitely a troll, enjoying the attention he receives from upset citizens and keeps doing this over and over again. He has reached day 5 in only 6 out of his 37 towns this season, while in this current 38th one, he is infected on day 2 and will not last long. He only played 1 town last season where he died on the first day, though in season 8 he reached day 5 in only 3 towns out of 59 and does not have a single hardcore LMS to his name. How is this strategy of "selfish" play benefiting him? It is not, he benefits from enjoying the trolling other players.

Some of us have invested a lot in this game and will not quit so easily and I do not expect anything different from players such as him, though a bit more pressure needs to be applied to trolls trying to ruin the game for everyone and upset as many people as they can, rather than defending their actions as "selfish play" which is most certainly not the case.

These matters should be dealt with more urgency as the player base appears to be in constant state of decline.

Jedermann

It's not that hard to have a look at peoples souls and determine the problematic players in a town, either taking immediate measures or watching every step they make and being ready.

The type of player that's discussed here (starts doing nonsense on day 1) is easy to recognize and shun/hang, right?

And it's not avoidable that you have some more or less selfish players in a random (non-meta) jump, players that grow inactive, players who die, etc. - even with super strict rules.

After all D2N isn't about joining a town and not worrying about anyone doing bad stuff, that's what the gallows are there for.

Either you accept a few percent "bad" players every town who are gonna be killed off, or you have to restrict who joins that town (thus playing in a meta or meta like structure).

As long as the game mechanics designed to take action against bad guys are still usuable (e.g. not a meta coalition of griefers jumping and shunning players, players specifically following other players around to spoil their experience, players repeatedly dieing on day 1 by purpose), I don't see a reason for the crows to take action.

As to naming&shaming in the world forums, that easily escalates and I don't think it'd be a good thing (or provide any benefit except maybe emotional satisfaction for the players who name&shame because they are pissed).

Oh, and just to make it clear, I'm neither a griefer nor do I like griefers

The gist of the changes is that STARTING NOW, we are able to deter some of the early game selfish play. Players that join towns and immediately start punching people or taking other actions to kill players prior to day 5 of a town will be dealt with as a griefer.

On february 27, 2016
shlominus

the main problem with "selfish play" is that sometimes it only differs from griefing by intention.

the game obviously provides a lot of ways to act selfishly that noone would ever consider griefing. eating people as a ghoul, building up your home early, even closing the gates on people in the endgame... it would be easy to find many more examples. being selfish is built into the game and the conflicts caused by that is part of what makes the game fun.

on the other hand there's plenty you can do that is in no way prohibited by the rules, but will reduce other players enjoyment of the game. you can stir up trouble or give bad advice in the forums without actually spamming or trolling. you can manipulate the map or fdtd (prove that with a screenshot!). you can sabotage construction by "accidentally" taking the required resources cause you needed that vodka even more to build your home or consider the portal lock to be crucial to any town. hens for the chicken coop? nah, you butcher them cause you like chicken better than a tasty dish from that obnoxious hero. the list, even more than the one about actual selfish play, could go on and on...

noone's going to report you for that (and even if they did nothing would happen) and while you can shun or hang offenders who do that, a griefer will simply move on to the next town and start over. they have already accomplished their goal and even got a distinction for it. great, right?

once a player displays a pattern of such behaviour, it's likely they are doing it intentionally, to harass everyone else.

lets look at the definiton of griefing:
"A griefer is a player in a multiplayer video game who deliberately irritates and harasses other players within the game..."

"A griefer derives pleasure primarily or exclusively from the act of annoying other users..."

from the griefers point of view annoying others is what they desire from the game, so you could argue that they are actually just "playing selfishly" when they intentionally do things to reduce others enjoyment of the game. looking at it like that there could never be any ingame action that can be considered griefing. everything would be "selfish". you can draw the line at some arbitrary points ("no attacks early on, later it's ok" ), but that way you simply provide guidelines for potential griefers, you don't stop the griefing itself. you simply reduce it slightly.

did they open the gates cause they tought it might improve their chaneces of winning lms? or because they were being an ass andd enjoyed the fact that everybody else was pissed off?

we'll never know. we have no means of knowing the intent for any action. what we do have is a way to measure the effect their play has on others. or we would have if there was no "naming and shaming"-ban. because the self-policing you seek is impossible if people are not allowed to openly talk about potential griefers. if someone is causing people to be mad more often than not, then they are a problem player, it's as simple as that. keeping such a player around hurts everyone else and, in the long run, the game itself.

not allowing naming and shaming causes more harm than good. potential griefers would be instashunned and the harm they could do would be greatly reduced, simply and swiftly, with ingame features. but you can only "shun on sight" if you know who to shun. on the other hand, you still get the complaint-posts, you just have to shut them down all the time. people aquire a reputation for a reason.

if they want to change their ways? noone is stopping them from starting a new account or trying to convince people they have changed.

also, once the whole community (minus a few idiots who cheer them on) considers someone a griefer, they probably are, no matter what the rules say about the matter. in such a case the rules should most likely be changed. smart griefers will always try to find a way to work around the rules. it's part of what they do. to be acting within the (letter of the) rules and still pissing people off? win-win for the griefer.

the most important thing is looking at the pattern of a potential problem player's actions. player souls are invaluable for that purpose. if you looked at gatekeepers soul it was obvious that he never intended to "play selfishly". well, unless you believe that he considered his efforts to be worth it despite dying on day 0-2 in 90%+ of his towns. he was only successful by one measure: pissing off as many people as possible, by the most basic definition of griefing.

if a player plays "normally", but in a selfish way, then their soul will, over time, display that. if they are griefing, it will display that too, probably even more blatantly. even if no rules were explicitely broken, you can usually tell who is intentionally causing problems and who isn't.

i hope with gatekeeper gone there won't be that many serious griefing problems in the future (although, lets face it, most likely he will be back), but you can never know. having a player hurt one town now and then is part of the deal (it's what the gallows is there for, after all). only if there's little else a player does it become a problem.

there will always be some kind of subjective decision involved (unless you provide a definite list of griefing actions, explicitly allowing everything else, which would be terrible in my opinion), but i consider that to be a good thing. the current system wouldn't even have to be changed much.

tl;dr

-griefing and selfish play sometimes only differ by intention, something we can never truly know
-"naming and shaming" helps more than it hurts and is necessary for making actual selfpolicing possible
-look at player souls and patterns of player behaviour, if there are complaints
-listen to the community, they know who hurts the game

On february 27, 2016
Corvus Epithumia

Because it's easier to respond here than to points above...

shlominus-griefing and selfish play sometimes only differ by intention, something we can never truly know

Die2Nite is somewhat of an anomaly to this rule. Any other game, I'd tend to agree (though point out that there's a presumption of innocence until proven guilty).

In Die2Nite, the developers distinctly and purposefully put options there that make it worth it to play against what the rest of the town wants. They even put a monetary reward for it (LMS) - but that's still only applicable after day 5.

For those reasons, regardless of stated or unstated intention, it's very easy to call something griefing if it has no benefit to the player doing it (either in survival or distinctions) or could lead to someone's death prior to day 5.



shlominus-"naming and shaming" helps more than it hurts and is necessary for making actual self-policing possible

That's been a strict rule of the forum since the beginning and isn't going to change any time soon.

Here's the problem with your policy (and go with this analogy here).

I'm your local cop. I see a few things, but mostly rely on the community to report things to me so I can go investigate.

Under naming and shaming, you've got the whole community (or a large part of it) at a community meeting that I may or may not be at. In this meeting, Joe decides that because he heard screaming at Mary's house last night, she obviously murdered Jane because Mary's just that kind of person. Now the whole community is riled up - which leads to vigilante violence and destruction. Now there are more people caught in the crossfire and is Joe to blame for starting any of this? Did Mary really do anything wrong?

All Joe needed to do was call me and say "hey, I heard this horrid screaming next door and I think someone may be hurt." And you can bet I'm gonna check it out and, if necessary, haul Mary off to jail. If it's her second strike, she even gets the death penalty with no appeals. It's a pretty harsh system, when you think about it. And FAR more effective than getting everyone riled up.

I'm not asking for you guys to self-police. I'm asking you to report the offenders so we can do the policing. There's a large difference there.


shlominus-look at player souls and patterns of player behaviour, if there are complaints

This is a good idea and something I'll take into consideration, but it's still less telling than a simple screenshot of actual griefing. The best I can offer if this is all I have to go on is possibly shooting the person an informal warning that their play-style may constitute griefing if they continue.


shlominus-listen to the community, they know who hurts the game

Do they always, though? Have you really never seen the community get outraged at a player for some perceived offense?

Though honestly, I do listen to the community. And I do have a pretty good idea of who the serials are - and I want them gone as much as the rest of you do. But returning to that police analogy above, there's no way I'm going to sentence Mary to death simply to find out later that her TV was too loud while she was watching Saw.

All that REALLY has to happen is for someone that sees griefing to report it. By the time it happens twice, the griefer is gone - usually long before they become a problem to the point where the community is up in arms about anything at all.

Corvus Epithumia

I'm not going to go point by point, mostly because you make good ones and there's no arguing most of it.

It *could* be easier for us to check into things, sure. But when D2N was created, there was never a plan to get rid of griefers. The system we do have is because we were as sick of griefers as the rest of the community (I suppose it helps that we're members, as well) so we worked something out with buzzard's approval that was at least a step in the right direction.

Unfortunately, asking for new development and getting it has about the same odds as winning a decently major prize in the lottery. It's not impossible, but it's also not likely. The question has been posed as to whether anyone even has a tool like that or if the devs/buzzard have to go digging into databases if they want to find that kind of information. We'll see what, if anything, comes of it. But for this conversation, we need to assume that something like that is off the table. I'm looking for suggestions that, within our current abilities, will allow us to more effectively combat griefing.

The "problem" with cases like gatekeeper's is that he got his initial warning and more or less changed his habits. He stopped crossing the line, but boy did he walk right up to it. And every time he got bitched about fed into his ego. (You all do know that giving a troll attention is exactly what he wants, right?) I'm not going to punish someone for rules they broke before they were rules. Likewise, I'm not going to punish someone that isn't actually breaking the rules. It sucked for the rest of us to put up with his antics, but it'd be like banning someone for rp in the forums that people may not like, but doesn't actually break any rules. I'm really trying NOT to be that moderator that cracks down on every single little thing - but there has to be a consistency in that at the same time.

shlominus

all very sensible, but like i said, if the rules allow someone to intentionally annoy many, many others without any repercussions, then the rules need to be changed. "walking right up to the line" was part of his griefing (and only possible because of his "over the line"-past).

in my mind, someone would have needed to make a decision and in this case that decision was obvious. if you are abusing the letter of the rules to keep harassing and trolling, you have to go. if you are feeding off of your earlier actions that are now against the rules, you have to go. if your soul shows 200+ shunnings and very little productive activity, you have to go. to put it simply: if you are a problem for the community, you have to go. gatekeeper was a problem, yet he was allowed to stay. rules are there to benefit the community, not for their own sake.

add a line to the rules explicitly stating that if a players overall activities are a problem for the majority of others, then they have to go, even if they didn't directly break any explicit rules. you'd have to bend the rules hard for quite some time for that to show on your soul, but once you reached that point it's over. every player can look at a soul page and if they think someone isn't playing in a way to help themselves but to harm others for his enjoyment, then they can report them just like they would any other griefer. you look a the soul and when convinced you warn them that if they keep up acting the way they are, they will get banned. that way extreme cases like gatekeeper can be dealt with easily. no naming and shaming needed, just common sense.

harming the rest of the community by having rules in place that protect the potential griefer seems weird. this is not reality. noone is being put in jail without proof. nobody loses their job. only an ingame-reputation is ruined (and everyone is free to start over with a new account and play "nice".). someone is banned from playing a browser-game because practically everyone wants them gone. unless you perceive the community as a bullying, pitchfork carrying mob that wants to drive harmless players away with baseless accusations, the community should always come first. i would argue a lot different if we were talking about real legal procedures, but this is a game we are talking about and you shouldn't apply the same principles as you would to real legal proceedings. i admire that you try, but i fear that sometimes it's too much of a good thing.

lets face it, gatekeeper got sloppy. with a little more discipline he could have stayed a thorn in everyone's side for as long as he liked. is that a situation that the griefing rules should produce?

as for not giving trolls any attention...

all very sensible, but like i said, if the rules allow someone to intentionally annoy many, many others without any repercussions, then the rules need to be changed. "walking right up to the line" was part of his griefing (and only possible because of his "over the line"-past).

in my mind, someone would have needed to make a decision and in this case that decision was obvious. if you are abusing the letter of the rules to keep harassing and trolling, you have to go. if you are feeding off of your earlier actions that are now against the rules, you have to go. if your soul shows 200+ shunnings and very little productive activity, you have to go. to put it simply: if you are a problem for the community, you have to go. gatekeeper was a problem, yet he was allowed to stay. rules are there to benefit the community, not for their own sake.

add a line to the rules explicitly stating that if a players overall activities are a problem for the majority of others, then they have to go, even if they didn't directly break any explicit rules. you'd have to bend the rules hard for quite some time for that to show on your soul, but once you reached that point it's over. every player can look at a soul page and if they think someone isn't playing in a way to help themselves but to harm others for his enjoyment, then they can report them just like they would any other griefer. you look a the soul and when convinced you warn them that if they keep up acting the way they are, they will get banned. that way extreme cases like gatekeeper can be dealt with easily. no naming and shaming needed, just common sense.

harming the rest of the community by having rules in place that protect the potential griefer seems weird. this is not reality. noone is being put in jail without proof. nobody loses their job. only an ingame-reputation is ruined (and everyone is free to start over with a new account and play "nice".). someone is banned from playing a browser-game because practically everyone wants them gone. unless you perceive the community as a bullying, pitchfork carrying mob that wants to drive harmless players away with baseless accusations, the community should always come first. i would argue a lot different if we were talking about real legal procedures, but this is a game we are talking about and you shouldn't apply the same principles as you would to real legal proceedings. i admire that you try, but i fear that sometimes it's too much of a good thing.

lets face it, gatekeeper got sloppy. with a little more discipline he could have stayed a thorn in everyone's side for as long as he liked. is that a situation that the griefing rules should produce?

On february 29, 2016
shlominus

i keep bringing up that one case because it highlights the problems with the current system. gatekeeper was possible within the system and that proves that there are flaws. if you don't want to accept that then we really are wasting our time. you say he was a problem? how is that even possible if the system works as intended? how could he be a problem for such a long time if the system deals with problem players? he was only banned because he snapped and openly attacked people, one of the few actions actually sanctioned. the current system can only identify and ban dumb griefers.

he wasn't a problem because he played "within the rules". he was a problem cause everyone knew that he broke the rules and still wasn't banned. he was rubbing it in all the time. he never played in a selfish manner. all he cared about was causing trouble. he died on day 0-2 in the vast majority of towns he was in. that's not selfish. he played within the rules cause the rules were not up to dealing with his kind of harassment.

if you don't realise that someone could create an account, stay within the rules and still harass and grief as much as they liked and be hated by everyone after only a short time, then i don't know what to say. i enjoy the game too much to waste my time proving that, but it would be a very simple exercise indeed.

if you want to catch griefers before they grow into gatekeeper-proportions you'd have to change the rules.

either present a definite list of actions that make someone a griefer. that list would obviously have to be updated whenever someone found a loophole. the downside of such a list would be that it would also be a guideline for potential griefers to work with.

or take a more subjective approach and judge people by their overall activities and the reaction of the community towards them. the downside of this approach is the obvious potential for wrong calls, as with any subjective decision.

the current system does none of those things and is easily exploitable by a smart griefer.

someone suggested a "sheriff" system. that actually sounds like a great idea. a few well established players keeping an eye on the community seems like a good idea.

On march 1, 2016
Corvus Epithumia
MegajefI do think the system failed with gatekeeper, but I think he was a special case because he knew how to exploit where the line was drawn, and I believe it's possible that others could follow in his footsteps, but that is a lot of work for the common griefer.

Yes and no. On both counts.

Gatekeeper spent years pissing people off. There's no denying that. And everything he did at the time was 100% legal because there were no rules against griefing. At all.

When we finally put the rules in place, we got an immediate report about him and he got his official warning. That worked exactly as intended.

Then everyone decided that it was more important to whine in the forums (sometimes rightfully so), than actually send in a report when he crossed the line. So instead of having anything at all to go off of for the final strike, he got to continue pissing people off.

Using that logic, we'd be missing a lot of great players if we retroactively enforced rules or if we bent to the whims of the community and their demands for mob justice.

Those of you that have been around for a long time can remember various instances of bullying. Most of the active forum members were on at least one side of said bullying. But should we really be banning people and deleting accounts based on that? (Hint: No. No, we shouldn't.)

With the rules as they stand now, another griefer like gatekeeper is never going to get to that point. People have admitted already that most of the reason he was a problem while playing selfishly, is because everyone was already so upset with him.

MegajefBut I still think it's ridiculous that no admins or mods have access to the town forums and gazette in extreme cases.

Admins technically do have access, but how difficult it is to get to, I'm not sure. But we have one admin for all of the English games... who's really in charge of marketing and not even supposed to be an admin. We're lucky that he's as responsive as he is - and as supportive!

As for the town forums, we crows do have access to any thread that has a post reported in it. If you feel there's something we need to see, report it. If you feel a simple report might not be obvious enough, report it then send us a message. I fully admit that when I'm going through reported posts, I'm looking to see if that post breaks a rule or not and may or may not read the surrounding posts for context.

We crows are volunteers that love the game and want to see it succeed. Keep in mind that we're players, just like you. We're not perfect and the occasional poke if you think we missed something is not a bad thing. Just be polite about it instead of screaming at us in all caps with unreasonable demands.

Players who pass the grifing quiz can be ready for future grifers.

Example.

1. Player joins the town, takes a bunch of useful items from the bank and stores them in his chest.
What will you do?

a) Take a screenshot and report the player to corvus and delete his account.
b) Shun the player.
c) Attack the player and wound him for hoarding items that the town needs.
d) Leave him be.
___________________________________________

2. Player 1 joins the town and immediately attacks Player 2 and wounds them. When you ask Player 1 why he did this, he says that Player 2 attacked Player 1 in a previous town and Player 1 got wounded and died from infection and now Player 1 attacked him in retaliation. What will you do?

a) Tell Player 1 and Player 2 to forget about what happened in the previous town and ask both players to just move on and start over in this new town.

b) Tell Player 1 that 2 wrongs do not make a right and report him to corvus for grifing.

c) Attack Player 1 to settle the rivalry between him and Player 2.

d) Assume that Player 1 is lying and is just making up this story just to get away with grifing and then shun him.

___________________________________________

3. A Player joins the town and, while there are still people outside the town, the Player closes the gates, leaving those people to die outside the town during the zombie attack. What do you do?

a) Report the player to corvus with a screenshot and delete his account.

b) Shun the player

c) Lock him outside so he can die during the zombie attack like this fellow citizens.

d) Do nothing

____________________________________________

The guy then tells you that you have to heal him with bandages or else he will die from his infected wound. There are bandages located outside the town but they are guarded by zombies in the zones. The guy tells you that you should take several weapons from the bank and put them in your inventory so that you can defend yourself while retrieving the bandages to heal the wounded player.
When you take the weapons, the guy secretly takes another screenshot but does not tell you this.
Then when you go outside to retrieve the items, the guy takes another screenshot secretly.
When you arrive to the location of the bandages you realize that there are no bandages at the location. You head back to town to tell the guy that there are no bandages.
However, you find that the town is locked and you tell the guy to open the gate but the guy keeps the town locked.
Then you die at the town gates during the zombie attack.

A few hours later, you get a message from Corvus and Buzzard telling you that they are going to delete your account because you grifed and they reveal to you the screenshots they recieved of you grifing.


It is now clear that the guy tricked you into attacking an innocent player, taking items from the bank, and going outside and dying at the town gates (which is something alot of grifers do), and then the guy reported you to corvus and buzzards along with the fake evidence of you grifing so to make it look as if you grifed and then went outside at 0/0 to die.

factoryman942
Corvus Cloud

Griefing is a series of deliberate actions taken solely to harm the town with no benefit to oneself.

Selfish Play includes actions which may harm others, but still allows for personal gain. However, punching others and "hiding" from retaliation does rise to the level of griefing. Important Update: Extreme examples of selfish play prior to day 5 may fall into our new griefing policies. You are still free to boost your own survival chances at any time, but actively trying to kill others through selfish play mechanisms are now disallowed prior to day 5.

Generally, griefing falls into a few specific scenarios.

1) Griefer punches as many people as possible, hides at 0/0 then dies during the first few days of the town by running into the desert or by some other deliberate action at any point during the town. Important Update: Repeatedly attacking people recklessly in the first days of town can be considered griefing and will be dealt with accordingly.

2) Griefer takes some or all important items from the bank (that provide no benefit in the world outside) and runs outside to die.

Bla bla, hypothetical situation which occurred in my town.

Person X is angry at Person Y. Person X takes a few AP-based items from the bank, including three drugs, and punches Person Y multiple times. Person X is now addicted from taking two of these drugs, and moves 3 squares away from the town along the axis.

Person X has publicly stated in a Twinoid chat that Person Y was hoping for the town to survive for a long time, and that they, Person X, "wanted to shit on that". Person X claims on this Twinoid Chat that they are out of AP, and camps for the night in the World Beyond.

((The town had a Watchtower upgraded to Level 5, and if Person X had moved two squares in one direction and then one in another, they would still have been within range to teleport back to town.))

The next day, Person X returns to the town from the World Beyond. Person X places the third drug they had back in the bank, and dies from withdrawal that night.


Would this situation of Person X having camped in the World Beyond count as having hidden from retaliation, making this a reportable offence?

Corvus Cloud
Updated October 22 2015

Griefing is not allowed in Die2Nite. Those that do grief will receive a warning along with a two week ban. If they choose to ignore the warning and continue, their Twinoid account will be deleted.

However, there is a difference between griefing and selfish play. Selfish play still is and will continue to be allowed. So how do we tell the difference?

Griefing is a series of deliberate actions taken solely to harm the town with no benefit to oneself.

Selfish Play includes actions which may harm others, but still allows for personal gain. However, punching others and "hiding" from retaliation does rise to the level of griefing. Important Update: Extreme examples of selfish play prior to day 5 may fall into our new griefing policies. You are still free to boost your own survival chances at any time, but actively trying to kill others through selfish play mechanisms are now disallowed prior to day 5.

Generally, griefing falls into a few specific scenarios.

1) Griefer punches as many people as possible, hides at 0/0 then dies during the first few days of the town by running into the desert or by some other deliberate action at any point during the town. Important Update: Repeatedly attacking people recklessly in the first days of town can be considered griefing and will be dealt with accordingly.

2) Griefer takes some or all important items from the bank (that provide no benefit in the world outside) and runs outside to die.

DO NOT "name and shame" players in this thread. Send your reports in and let us figure it out. If there's action to be taken, we'll take it.
